Title: So you just installed Signal, now what?
Date: 2020-06-05 07:33:25
Category: Tech
Tags: signal, privacy, security, protest, blacklivesmatter
Status: draft

<center><img src="data:image/webp;base64,"/></center>
<center>Edward Snowden uses Signal "every day" and you should too! ([Download the sticker pack](https://signalstickers.com/pack/e182457d2e5d558d4d5ee14e5f2512f3))</center>


So, you've just installed [Signal](https://signal.org/) because someone told you to or you read about it in the news. Now what?

(Not on Signal yet? Check out [this video from The Intercept](https://theintercept.com/2017/05/01/cybersecurity-for-the-people-how-to-keep-your-chats-truly-private-with-signal/) or a [guide for beginners from the Freedom of the Press Foundation](https://freedom.press/news/signal-beginners/).)

Just say hi to your friends who are already on Signal! Look through [some sticker packs](https://signalstickers.com/) and send some cute/funny ones like [BART plants](https://signalstickers.com/pack/a27b2ee11656275c0f900026e1327541). Or browse through GIFs [in a fully private manner](https://signal.org/blog/signal-and-giphy-update/). The longest-running Signal group I'm in just shares photos of cute goats.

Ultimately, Signal aims to provide the same functionality as every other messaging app out there, except that they don't want to know anything about you. They can't read your messages, see your contact list, who's in your group, hear your voice/video calls, and so on (this was [proven in court](https://signal.org/bigbrother/eastern-virginia-grand-jury/) after a subpoena). This is referred to as being [end-to-end encrypted](https://ssd.eff.org/en/module/what-should-i-know-about-encryption).

Most people don't enter a conversation knowing that they're going to say something in dissent of those in power or advocate for civil disobedience - it usually happens naturally. The more conversations that begin on Signal, the more likely that you're going to say something potentially dangerous over a safe channel. 

Your messages are generally safe from government subpoenas or attackers trying to [tamper with your connection](https://ssd.eff.org/en/glossary/man-middle-attack). But your messages are still readable on your own phone and whoever you're talking with. If police take your phone while you're protesting, it's important to have a passcode or configure Signal's [Screen Lock](https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/360007059572-Screen-Lock) feature to keep your messages safe.

Alternatively, you can use Signal's [disappearing messages](https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/360007320771-Set-and-manage-disappearing-messages) feature to have messages vanish after a certain amount of time. If you're coordinating a protest, there's no real need to keep those messages around after the fact. Or if someone asks you for your Netflix password, have it disappear after a few minutes. (Sidenote: [journalists should always enable disappearing messages](https://freedom.press/training/blog/why-reporters-should-always-turn-signals-disappearing-messages/).) Photos and videos can be sent in [view once](https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/360038443071-View-Once-Media) mode (à la Snapchat) if they don't need to be kept around forever.

Signal also lets you set a max conversation length limit (Settings -> Storage -> Conversation length limit). Any messages over that limit will be deleted, allowing you to keep conversations more ephemeral and limits the amount of messages revealed if your device falls into the wrong hands.

It's worth noting that the fact you are using Signal is not private. Anyone on Signal who has your phone number can see that they can send you a message through Signal. In fact, Signal will notify people who have your number when you sign up that you can now be reached through Signal. The more people who use Signal for every day messaging will help cloak the activists, journalists and dissidents who rely on Signal to protect themselves from harm.

One major difference from other chat applications is that because your messages are not stored on the Signal server, they're only on your phone. If you lose your phone, get a new device or uninstall/reinstall the app, you'll lose your previous history of messages. Android users can [create and restore a backup](https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/360007059752-Backup-and-Restore-Messages), while iOS users will [soon be able to transfer messages from one device to another](https://community.signalusers.org/t/beta-feedback-for-the-upcoming-ios-3-9-release/14290).

It's important to understand that while Signal provides a level of usability, privacy and security that no other messaging app comes close to right now, it's may not be the perfect solution that solves all of your problems or fears. 

Once you've gotten the hang of Signal, spread the word! Invite your friends and family to join too. If you can afford to, please [donate to the Signal Technology Foundation](https://signal.org/donate/). More technical/comfortable users can sign up to join [Signal's beta testing program](https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/360007318471-How-do-I-join-Signal-s-beta-).
